content.title: Open Aortic Aneurysm Repair - Surgical Principles
content.summary: Traditional surgical approach for aortic aneurysm repair involving aortic cross-clamping, aneurysm resection, and graft interposition, remaining the gold standard for durability.

definitions.definition: Surgical procedure involving laparotomy or thoracotomy, aortic cross-clamping, aneurysm resection, and replacement with prosthetic graft.
Method where the aneurysm sac is opened, graft sewn inside, and native aortic wall wrapped around the graft for hemostasis and tissue separation.

key_concepts.explanation: Transperitoneal: midline laparotomy, full exposure, bilateral iliac access. Retroperitoneal: left flank incision, less fluid shifts, better for hostile abdomen. Thoracoabdominal: thoracoretroperitoneal incision for TAAA.

Cross-clamping increases afterload (SVR up 40%), preload, and MAP. Unclamping causes hypotension from reperfusion vasodilation and metabolite washout. Gradual release and volume loading mitigate hemodynamic swings.
Dacron (polyester): most common, available in woven and knitted forms. Woven is stronger, knitted is more compliant. PTFE: alternative, lower porosity. Size: typically 1.5-2x normal aortic diameter.
Cell salvage (autotransfusion). Sequential clamping to minimize ischemia. IMA reimplantation if backbleeding is poor. Retrograde perfusion for visceral/renal protection in TAAA.

evidence.finding: OAR has higher perioperative mortality (5.5%) but superior long-term durability with fewer reinterventions compared to EVAR
No difference in long-term survival between EVAR and OAR; OAR had lower reintervention rates

clinical_pearls: OAR remains preferred for young patients due to superior durability
Retroperitoneal approach is advantageous for inflammatory AAA and hostile abdomen
Always check IMA backbleeding - poor flow may require reimplantation
Adequate hydration before unclamping prevents declamping hypotension
Left renal vein can be safely ligated if needed for exposure (collaterals exist)
learning_objectives: Compare transperitoneal and retroperitoneal surgical approaches
Describe the hemodynamic consequences of aortic cross-clamping
Select appropriate graft material and size for aortic repair
State long-term outcomes of open repair versus EVAR
